conclusion: To determine whether the particle is undergoing acceleration or deceleration, we need to analyze the graph of the reciprocal of the velocity \( \frac{1}{v} \) as a function of the displacement \( x \).
The graph shows a straight line with points A and B on it, where \( \frac{1}{v} \) is plotted against displacement \( x \).

premise: The slope of the line in the graph represents the acceleration of the particle.
conclusion: Identify the slope of the line: The slope of a line is given by the change in the y-coordinate (velocity) divided by the change in the x-coordinate (displacement).

premise: The slope of the line \( AB \) is given by: \( \text{slope} = \frac{\frac{1}{v_A} - \frac{1}{v_B}}{x_A - x_B} \)

premise: The slope of the line \( AB \) is negative.
conclusion: Determine the direction of the acceleration: The negative slope indicates that the particle is moving in the negative direction of the x-axis, meaning the particle is decelerating.
